node.bodyText:
This commit add app settings to redirect a page with ssowat.
Exemple of use:

sudo yunohost app setting $app redirected_urls -v "{'/ynhpanel.js':'$path/menu.js'}"

This allow to redirect the ynh_panel.js, like that I can display a menu on all pages in place of the square yunohost panel.
As discussed, a new category - e.g. ssowat - with actions for adding/changing/deleting SSOwat rules - instead of using app_setting - should be added. So it will be subject to change!

node.bodyText:
Hi, this is a extension to handle email alias, based on this post: https://forum.yunohost.org/t/add-a-redirection-mail-alias-without-attaching-it-to-a-yunohost-account/182
This will just create an email alias in LDAP that forwards messages to an email list. It accept email list delimited by commas to add/remove email in bulk. This is a first version, it seems to work well on my yunohost but there are probably untested case.
There is an init function to initialize the LDAP schema on a existing installation but maybe there is a better way to do this. Please tell me if you see any improvement to be done.
A cool feature would be an "all" alias, an email list for all yunohost user on a domain.

What a gorgeous contribution <3
Now we will have to plug this work on the Web interface and remove the old way to handle aliases (yunohost user update myuser --add-mailalias alias@domain.org)
Epic job though 👍
EDIT: Ok I have just been informed that it is slightly different than the current behavior. Therefore we just need to make a new interface to handle this :)

wow ! I should look into the pr list more often. this is awesome and I dreamed of having something like that several times.
sadly it now needs a rebase.
it would be such a shame to leave all this work sleeping here...
This PR has been rebased/reworked in #176

node.bodyText:
The current default configuration of dnsmasq allows anyone to do DNS recursive requests from the internet. Each server with this configuration is a candidate for participating to a DNS DDoS Amplification Attack.
Setting the resolv-file parameter is the only way I found to disable the forwarding to upstream servers. It could be added directly into dnsmasq.conf, instead of in each zone file as in my commit.

node.bodyText:
Was quite broken :)
In fact, ynh dyndns client was setting all AAAA records to "::" which is supposed to be "The Unspecified Address", a non-routable address.
However, in practice, this unspecified address is considered as loopback (try ping6 :: to figure out), and causing non-delivery when an IPv6-enabled MTA try to reach your dyndns domain, with that kind of error :
 The mail system <john.doe@example.nohost.me>: mail for example.nohost.me loops back to myself

So it's a severe bug, *preventing all .nohost.me domains to work reliably . Thus, I suggest, after review, to backport this fix on stable and testing as well.
It's good step towards #25 btw.
Any review/feedback on that ?
Add some pseudo-random ping to @jvaubourg @kloadut @jeromelebleu ;)

woa didn't see it.
LGTM 👍

Very nice, this was a huge bug for me.
I'm not a Python expert, I can't really review this code. But I seen this comment: Get the IPv6 address given by radvd and sanitize it. With the VPN Client app (e.g. Internet Cube), the IP addresses to use in the DNS correspond to the IPs delivered by the VPN, and not the wired network.
The only solution I know is to use the routing table. For example, with ip r g 2001:913::8 or ip r g 80.67.188.188 (or other remote addresses), we exactly know the IPs and the interfaces used for going out.

But I seen this comment: Get the IPv6 address given by radvd and sanitize it.
With the VPN Client app (e.g. Internet Cube), the IP addresses to use in the DNS correspond to the IPs delivered by the VPN, and not the wired network.

I just kept the logic as it was : get the first global v6 address found.

The only solution I know is to use the routing table. For example, with ip r g 2001:913::8 or ip r g 80.67.188.188 (or other remote addresses), we exactly know the IPs and the interfaces used for going out.

That's a clever one.
My feeling is that changing the address selection logic normally goes to another PR. That said, this PR may break "working" IPv6 installations by creating unexpected DNS records, and worse, leak an address that the VPN mechanism should have kept secret.
So, I 'm working on integrating what you suggest.
@jvaubourg actually, as we rely on /etc/yunohost/interface it should be fine, what is the value of /etc/yunohost/interface on a yunohost installation using the VPN app ?

on my olimex board using vpnclient_ynh :
admin@olinux:~$ cat /etc/yunohost/interface                                                                                        
eth0

on my olimex board using vpnclient_ynh :
admin@olinux:~$ cat /etc/yunohost/interface
eth0

Ok, I'm wondering if it's not a bug then, do any of you know what is the purpose of /etc/yunohost/interface ? shoult it contain tun0 while using vpnclient_ynh ?
The file is not used anymore. We should suppress it :)

The file is not used anymore. We should suppress it :)

Actually, it's used by this dyndns script :/

@JocelynDelalande Yup ! My bad..
I am making a fix to get the IPv6 address the same way than the current IPv4, by reaching ip6.yunohost.org
@kloadut I don't know… It is something we can do without relying on an external service (getting public ipv6), let's do it the propper way, don't you think ?
I guess we should, if we manage to do the same for IPv4 (and I don't know how to)
With ip6.yunohost.org we can forget about the interface name fetching

I guess we should, if we manage to do the same for IPv4

No, we can't, because we're using all the time a hack called NAT, but in IPv6 we don't use such hacks, that's the beauty :)

@JocelynDelalande I agree with you, we don't have to use an external service for that with IPv6. But, in fact, it is the easier way to find the public IPv6 to use in AAAA (considering that the privacy extension is not enabled, as expected on a server). Finding a way to do ip route get 80.67.188.188 with /proc files is just a bit of a mess...

If you successfully manage to do it, I can't be against it :-)
In the mean time, I pushed my working version (not released yet), feel free to adapt the part that you need.
1ceb125

@JocelynDelalande I agree with you, we don't have to use an external service for that with IPv6.
But, in fact, it is the easier way to find the public IPv6 to use in AAAA (considering that the privacy extension is not enabled, as expected on a server).

well, the way you suggested with routing decision and source adress seems just fine to me, no ? (I mean, appart the fact ip route output is a bit shitty to parse).

Finding a way to do ip route get 80.67.188.188 with /proc files is just a bit of a mess...

s/just a bit of a mess/impossible/ ?

@kloadut on a more meta note, no big deal but I would appreciate that you do not copy/paste changes of a PR to some new commit. As a contributor :

I like to review and amend my PR myself, at my pace, based on peer comments, taking time if it requires some discussion
I like being credited for my work (commit message)
I hate fixing conflict merge ;)

Thanks :)

node.bodyText:
The idea
We wanted to propose configuration updates on YunoHost instances for security and quality purposes. If the user has not modified her/his configuration files by her/himself, the configuration is automatically updated.
In the other hand, if a user has modified a configuration manually, we wanted to prevent this modification to be overwritten.
Usage
You can regenerate all the configuration at once, or one service at a time.
sudo yunohost service regenconf
# Or
sudo yunohost service regenconf -s nginx

Note that you can pass a --force argument as well to force configuration overriding.
Functioning
The action will compare a configuration file with one of a proposed set of templates and try to replace it, storing its modification at the same time.

If the action finds no difference between the proposed configuration file and the current one, it only stores a hash of the file in /etc/yunohost/services.yml
If the action finds a difference between the proposed configuration file and the current one, but the current one already had its hash stored and was not modified since, the proposed file overrides it.
If the action finds a difference between the proposed configuration file and the current one, either because the current file was not registered before or because a manual modification was applied since then, the action displays a warning in addition to a diff between the two files. In this case, the user is free to apply the proposed modifications manually, or override her/his modifications by passing --force to the action.

Side effect
We managed to merge all YunoHost packages into one: yunohost, which inherit all dependencies to services (postfix, slapd, etc.), the set of configuration templates, and the python script of the moulinette specific to YunoHost.
apt-fucking-get install yunohost
Youhou! \O/ #yolocowboy

node.bodyText: This is a non-working WIP for Let's encrypt
Just to make sure: does this work with multiple domains? Is it possible to automatically do this for all new domains?
Awesome
Awesome work ;-) Any news on it? Is it near to be merged?
For a more general comment: thanks a lot for doing this work <3

Hi,
@pyrech This probably won't be merged soon since it doesn't work.
@Psycojoker Thanks for the review. I agree with all your point. As you have probably see this was a quick and dirty PR ;) I was not aware of shutil lib which can replace some of the os.system call (and other should be replaced either by subprocess call or native os.xxx function like os.symlink).
Otherwise this was done before the public LE beta and some client usage have changed, this thread https://forum.yunohost.org/t/how-to-install-letsencrypt-certificates/1075 is more up to date. And there are some mistake like nginx need to be reload and metronome restarted after creating/renewing a cert.
Moreover some things have to be discussed before a proper LE integration like:

Is this a good idea to use the official LE client? It's very heavy and there is a bunch of other good client. Full list here: https://community.letsencrypt.org/t/list-of-client-implementations/2103
https://github.com/diafygi/acme-tiny/ and https://github.com/kuba/simp_le seems very good for yunohost usage.
Is revoke function really necessary with easy renewal and 90 days validity?
Is default to LE when creating a domain a good idea? Adding a domain will fail if DNS are not already propagated or configured for example, this can be a issue for yunohost dydns and need to be tested.

Unfortunatly I won't have time to work on this soon (I am about to move and change jobs, + christmas) :/ So if someone want to give it a try and maybe reuse some of my code go for it.

Hello,
@mbugeia thanks for your work! It's a good starting point.
The Let's Encrypt support will be implemented soon in the branch domain-enh under a new domain_cert action - or a new certificate category.
The goal is to have a specific action to generate SSL Certificates - using pure Python code - which allows to select what to use - e.g. self-signed certificate, existing CA or... Let's Encrypt!
See #180
Close because @alexAubin PR #180 is way more relevant.

node.bodyText:
Actually, this command being so stupidly simple, it could be backported to testing.
I have no idea on how I'm supposed to handle DKIM (it is supposed to be integrated now but I don't know where/how).

Example of generated DNS config for domain yolo.swag (ip has been replace for obvious reason):
@ 1400 IN A 123.123.123.123
* 1400 IN A 123.123.123.123

_xmpp-client._tcp 14400 IN SRV 0 5 5222 yolo.swag.
_xmpp-server._tcp 14400 IN SRV 0 5 5269 yolo.swag.
muc 1800 IN CNAME @
pubsub 1800 IN CNAME @
vjud 1800 IN CNAME @

@ 1400 IN MX 10 yolo.swag.
@ 1400 IN TXT "v=spf1 a mx ip4:123.123.123.123 -all"

I've just add to configure the DNS for a member who is at OVH. OVH being OVH, they have decided to do things their because fuck the world. Here is how it should look:
$TTL 86400
@   IN SOA dns14.ovh.net. tech.ovh.net. (2016012901 86400 3600 3600000 86400)
                         IN NS     ns14.ovh.net.
                         IN NS     dns14.ovh.net.
                         IN MX 5   $DOMAIN.
                         IN A      $IPV4
                         IN AAAA   $IPV6
                         IN TXT    "v=spf1 a mx ip4:$IPV4 ip6:$IPV6 -all"
*                        IN A      $IPV4
*                        IN AAAA   $IPV6
_xmpp-client._tcp        IN SRV    0 5 5222 $DOMAIN.
_xmpp-server._tcp        IN SRV    0 5 5269 $DOMAIN.

I don't know how to handle this wonderful special case. Another command? An option? Anyway, is it conceivable to have a template engine at disposition (like jinja2)? Because concatening strings is driving me a bit crazy.

what about adding a registrar agrument ?
Something like yunohost domain dns --domain=yolo.com --registrar=ovh
It sucks, but registrar sucks as well

We should add the DKIM TXT instruction too.
The instruction is listed in:
/etc/dkim/DOMAIN.mail.txt
Le 05/02/2016 10:29, Jérôme Lebleu a écrit :

Merged #119 #119.
—
Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
#119 (comment).

I wanted to had that too, but not one was able to tell how it works at the time I've written this command.
I'm adding this to my todolist.

It's possible to create if tags with .format, this will allow wayyyyy less horrible code http://makina-corpus.com/blog/metier/the-worlds-simplest-python-template-engine?utm_source=twitterfeed&utm_medium=twitter

Thanks for that beautiful command. I get this result:
# yunohost domain dns-conf moul.re
@ 1400 IN A 78.227.107.45
* 1400 IN A 78.227.107.45
@ 1400 IN AAAA 2a01:e34:ee36:b2d0:4a:9ff:fe82:8f7d
* 1400 IN AAAA 2a01:e34:ee36:b2d0:4a:9ff:fe82:8f7d

_xmpp-client._tcp 14400 IN SRV 0 5 5222 moul.re.
_xmpp-server._tcp 14400 IN SRV 0 5 5269 moul.re.
muc 1800 IN CNAME @
pubsub 1800 IN CNAME @
vjud 1800 IN CNAME @

@ 1400 IN MX 10 moul.re.
@ 1400 IN TXT "v=spf1 a mx ip4:78.227.107.45 ip6:2a01:e34:ee36:b2d0:4a:9ff:fe82:8f7d -all"
Is wildcards entries are relevant? I don't know in which use case they are used. May be separate them from @ entries as in documentation I have updated.
The result of this command use different TTL values. May be, we could use a default value as in updated documentation and if we want to modify this value we could use an option --ttl.
--ttl option is relevant, and should be easy to implement.

Yes, wildcards are totally relevant, adding them cost nothing and allows the user to add any subdomain he wants as installing one app per subdomain is a popular way of doing things (and actually a way more frequent modern way of doing this than installing an app per path).
I have no idea on which default value TTL should have tbh, for me it's more or less random or "the last one I've set". Okay for the option.
can't agree more with @Psycojoker about adding wildcards
Wow, wildcard entries are very usefull! Thanks for explanation.
I would like to implement the --ttl option. I will open a new pull request on unstable branch. How could I test my implementation? Where are located this scripts on the system?
use ynh-dev with the docker settings, you'll find this command in /yunohost/yunohost and you can use "./ynh-dev deploy" to test your modifications https://yunohost.org/#/dev_fr
Why can't I test modifications on a deployed testing YunoHost? Do I really need a dev environnement with ynh-dev? What's different? If so, I will try again to deploy ynh-dev with Docker.
Oh, you can totally do that, the file should be there for you /usr/lib/moulinette/yunohost/domain.py
Wow! thanks 😸

You'll need to edit actionmap file too, located at /usr/share/moulinette/actionsmap/yunohost.yml to add the ttl argument.
Then either run yunohost command without cache (yunohost --no-cache) or manually remove the actionmap cache located at /var/cache/moulinette/actionsmap/yunohost.pkl.
oh, yeah, don't forget to do that (remove the action map), otherwise your actions won't take effect https://github.com/YunoHost/ynh-dev/blob/master/ynh-dev#L152

node.bodyText:
This hides the Nginx version in error pages to make it harder for script kiddies to target vulnerabilities specific to a version. Before: 302 Found

302 Found

nginx/1.6.2
After: 302 Found

302 Found

nginx
I also did some whitespace cleanup. This is my first PR to get to know the yunohost codebase. I used https://yunohost.org/#/docker to test my changes and it worked relatively well but I'm wondering if you have any kind of automated testsuite or build system? Thank you for this great project!

Looks good to me.
( and no, there's actually no build system or automated testsuite. Some happy volunteers are working hard to make this happen )

Looks good to me too, except for the name of the new file.
Let's try to avoid common/utils/... and other meaningless names !
Otherwise 👍
we did similar modifications for other services (postfix, ...)

except for the name of the new file.

what about server.conf ? ( btw, I don't understand the purpose of the server.conf.sed file in data/templates/nginx )

Thanks for the reply, that's great to hear about the build system.
Regarding the file name, Nginx's default config file - /etc/nginx/nginx.conf - contains include /etc/nginx/conf.d/*.conf; so I figured we could have /etc/nginx/conf.d/common.conf to override any default config that is common, i.e. shared through all vhosts/sites.
Though I'm happy to rename it if you have a better suggestion @julienmalik?
can we merge as-is ? and eventually file an issue if you also feel the name should change ? I currently have no better alternative to propose (global.conf maybe?).
Also I'm surprised I discovered we don't override the default /etc/nginx/nginx.conf in regenconf. That would be a simple place to put it.
I prefer global.conf - I renamed it. Feel free to merge if you're happy with it.
@opi @jeromelebleu  : let's merge ?
Yes, and I agree to see later - as needed - to rename this file or move it somewhere else...

node.title: Display a more useful error message to a user with how to perform the recommanded action.

node.bodyText: …e last generation

do not merge yet.
actually the message is not that helpful, since we do not provide any way to "apply modification manually" : users can't apply their modifications unless they first run with --force. and then they need the old diff around, or they need to remember what they did to their file...
see also https://dev.yunohost.org/issues/172

IMHO we should be ultra-verbose in that case and better drive users into how to reapply their custom modifications over the new yunohost-maintainer version.
regenconf --force should :

check if it needs to save the  user-modified file (already done ?)
save the current user-modified file (already done I think in /home/yunohost.backup/conffiles)
report the location of the saved user-modified file explicitely in the logs
show diff between the user-modified file and the new "maintainer version."
follow-up in https://dev.yunohost.org/issues/172
Not valid anymore due to #138.

node.bodyText:
It rewrites some parts of the regen-conf but try to keep as much as possible the same logic - to prevent a too big refactoring. The main change is that configuration file regen is now handle by service_regen_conf directly - note that service_safecopy and service_saferemove have been removed.
Hooks are now called twice with the following arguments respectively:

"pre" $force $pending_dir: it's time for the script to generate and put each configuration file to update/remove into $pending_dir with the right directory tree. To remove one, just touch an empty file.
"post" $force $regen_conf_files: this second time, the script may fix permissions, restart services as needed - i.e. depending if some conf files have been updated, $regen_conf_files is a coma-sperated string of them.

Between this two executions, the service_regen_conf will look for any files under the $pending_dir and safely process them - either create, update or remove the proper system configuration.
TODO-list before merging

 Reinstate what's done in email-legacy hook - one indirect possibility would be to update the services.yml => see f96b2af.
 Check Debian package first installation and YunoHost post-install from the cli and the web admin - to validate d24cd49.

node.bodyText:
This patch will align the SSOwat conf produced by yunohost by the one asked by a coming patch to SSOwat.
The idea is to put applications details not in the users dict but in a separate dict. The user dict now only have a list of app id. This allow to have more details than name:url and remove duplicate information in the conf in case of more than one user.
That way of storing data reduce the cost of storing more information on app at the price of indirect access to the app details in SSOwat.
Related to Kloadut/SSOwat#58 and https://dev.yunohost.org/issues/302#change-919

node.bodyText:
It adds set -eu to each backup hook to ensure that it will fail on command error and/or unset variable. The goal is to prevent this situation where a system hook is considered as successful even if it failed. It will by the way also prevent to let the user think that he/she has a system backup - even if it's an empty one!
It also makes use of ynh_backup for each file/directory backup.
node.title: Harden backup hooks to handle errors

What's the goal of putting those filters there? From what I know and understand reading the documentation, it is a last-resort tool to work around server replies that break interoperability with the Postfix SMTP client, so it concerns more inbound email, isn't it?
Also, please note that if you move the file away from the plain folder, this script needs to be modified too to replace and copy this new configuration file.

Agreed with @jeromelebleu

Especially I think this is for smtp_header_checks ("FILTERS WHILE DELIVERING MAIL") : http://www.postfix.org/postconf.5.html#smtp_header_checks

node.bodyText:
This is needed by Dovecot - and especially by Sieve. If the permission is incorrectly set - as it was on my server: drwxrwsr-x root:man, managesieve will not be able to create any folder inside. Here is the error when trying to manage Sieve filters with Roundcube:
dovecot[1150]: managesieve(camille): Error: sieve-storage: mkdir_parents_chgrp(/var/mail/sievescript/camille/scripts//tmp) failed: Permission denied (euid=500(vmail) egid=8(mail) missing +w perm: /var/mail, we're not in group 12(man), dir owned by 0:12 mode=0775)
dovecot[1150]: managesieve(camille): Fatal: Failed to open Sieve storage.
node.title: [fix] Set /var/mail folder owners and permissions

node.title: Clean app fetchlist

node.bodyText:
Hello,
Right now yunohost app fetchlist only fetch the official app list by default and there is not easy way to fetch all list at once. I've chosen to modify this behavior to fetch all list by default if no url and name are provided.
I've included retrocomabitle code since YunoHost doesn't store each list url.
This PR depends on #159
You should probably read this diff to avoid having a mix with the other commits b787e3a...470636b
Cheers

You should also mention that you've chosen to store the repository url in a file named name.url! Also, I don't see where you write this file - except in backward compatible code - for a new repository...

Where should I mention that?
Indeed, the "add new url" process is not finished, I've forgot to test that.
I'm doing all of this once/if the PR 159 is merged to work on a fresh rebase.
I'll have a look after we merge #159
#159 is now merged

After discussing on the chat, we need to think what we want to do about that, especially about how we want to keep track of "registered" lists and how to migrate away from the old scheme. We should also stop that dirty trick with the cron job who re-write itself. Let's have a single default cron job in /etc/cron.daily/ who simply calls yunohost app fetchlist with no arguments and fetch all lists that are tracked.
If we don't plan to merge #195 soon, I'd personally go for a small hard-coded migration for this specifically (something like, at the beginning of app_fetchlist, if _using_old_scheme(): _migrate_to_new_fetchlist_scheme())

So btw for people who didn't follow the discussion on the chat with Bram : instead of having multiple .url to remember the url of each applist, we decided to have a single .json file stored in /etc/yunohost/ to store info about the known applists (except the applist themselves, which are still stored in serapate jsons, at the same place as before).
Still need to test if the postinstall change works, but in the meantime reviews are welcomed !
I just noticed that the permissions of the cron job might not be good (no +x), might need to fix that

Exceptions handling is really starting to feel like madness... But hopefully #274 should really help to have simpler code once it's there...
So, bumping again, hopefully for the last time :/
Well...
@Psycojoker : da0b003 should fix it :)

Comment from Bram on the chat (which I agree with :)) :

01:19:17 Bram>     open("/etc/cron.d/yunohost-applist-%s" % name, "w").write('00 00 * * * root yunohost app fetchlist -u %s -n %s > /dev/null 2>&1\n' % (url, name))
01:19:30 Bram> je me dit que ça serait peut être malin qu'on fasse un randint pour la minute
01:19:47 Bram> sinon là on dit basiquement à TOUS les yunohost "YOLO, DDoS nous pile à la même minute à minuit !"

Edit : after discussing with Bram, we agreed to implement this in a small PR after one
(Calling for merging approval again)

So there is 2 positive review (alexAubin and me).
As it is a medium decision we need at least one positive review more.
Agreed, we should definitely squash :P

node.title: [enh] Refactor applist management

node.bodyText: Strongest Ciphers / EECDH

I noticed that Calomel extension now say that SHA-1 is not secure with 4/15 as note.
SHA-256 give 15/15 as note.

I tried it.
It did not changed the SHA issue.

You only modified yunohost_admin.conf, but the server conf (server.tpl) also does embed ssl directives.
Best would probably be to factorize generic ssl options (all ssl_xxx except the certs) in a common file, to be used in domain specific conf and yunohost_admin.conf

What recommendation did you follow to set up these new cipher list and the rest ?
I think we used the Mozilla SSL conf generator : https://mozilla.github.io/server-side-tls/ssl-config-generator/
which is good since it quickly shows the corresponding supported clients.
The choice to harden ssl configuration usually has consequences on the number of supported clients (browsers), and on performance (client or server side). Ideally that's something that should be chosen by the admin, but yunohost is not yet ready for this kind of configuration.

Typically, it's here that we should think to introduce a settings management
In this case it could be:

Harden encryption (some old device couldn't reach this server)
Classic encryption
This one seems to be depending on #229
Closing because it seems to be superseded by #259

node.title: [enh] display file path on file_not_exist error

node.bodyText:
Hello,
Currently app_tmp_folder is a global variable that is modified during app related process (install, upgrade) here https://github.com/YunoHost/yunohost/compare/fix_435_340_326_maybe_311?expand=1#diff-c98834a0df97adaa917878824a06b38fL1174
This doesn't create any problem in CLI because once the command is finished, the program ends and at a new run the variable will be reseted.
But on the web interface, execpt if you restart the moulinette, this variable is still modified and you end up with those kind of errors:
CalledProcessError: Command '['wget', '-qO', '/var/cache/yunohost/from_file/opensondage_ynh-0af12d46ca521ccd0e652901e1462578bc27f9b9/zerobin_ynh-6819a3e219ad3204b75551c3debda2390b483103/zerobin_ynh-6819a3e219ad3204b75551c3debda2390b483103.zip', 'https://github.com/YunoHost-Apps/shellinabox_ynh/archive/7a3a13cda984173eaa873711a933a2c07f13fe3d.zip']' returned non-zero exit status 1

Notice the: /var/cache/yunohost/from_file/opensondage_ynh-0af12d46ca521ccd0e652901e1462578bc27f9b9/zerobin_ynh-6819a3e219ad3204b75551c3debda2390b483103/zerobin_ynh-6819a3e219ad3204b75551c3debda2390b483103.zip ?
It's this variable that has received several modifications at the line indicated and thus generated an unexisting path.
This path intent to remove the modification of the global variable and thus preventing kind of errors to occur.
It should not create new bug (I've been greping all around to be sure not to miss something and it runs in my vagrant), but I'm not 100% sure about that since using a global variable and modifying it tends to create very hard to predict behavior. Sadly the person who have written this code is not here anymore to check that.
On a side no I think that we should rename for uppercase all our global variables for readability, I'm ready to send a patch for that.
This should fix those bugs: https://dev.yunohost.org/issues/435 https://dev.yunohost.org/issues/340 https://dev.yunohost.org/issues/326 and maybe https://dev.yunohost.org/issues/311
Kind regards,
Oh yeah, regarding the strategy I've chosen: explicitly passed the new modified path around and use this one except of using a global variable for that.

As the extracted folder path is now returned, it should be enhanced at an upper level. I think this folder should be created randomly and safely using tempfile.mkdtemp. It will prevent any other related strange issues - or at least reduce them. What do you think?
I understand that you didn't wanted to modify to much things, but I've seen some remaining lines that could still cause some issues...

As the extracted folder path is now returned, it should be enhanced at an upper level. I think this folder should be created randomly and safely using tempfile.mkdtemp. It will prevent any other related strange issues - or at least reduce them. What do you think?

Regarding other problems, normally app_tmp_folder is wiped out everytime so I
can't see a conflict happening in the current form of the code but maybe you
have though about some other situations I don't have in mind.
See 
  
    
      yunohost/src/yunohost/app.py
    
    
         Line 1147
      in
      f682468
    
    
    
    

        
          
           if os.path.exists(app_tmp_folder): shutil.rmtree(app_tmp_folder) 
        
    
  

 
  
    
      yunohost/src/yunohost/app.py
    
    
         Line 1218
      in
      f682468
    
    
    
    

        
          
           if os.path.exists(app_tmp_folder): 
        
    
  


But that would probably indeed cleaner (but there are so many things to clean
in the code already :/ and indeed I've tried to make this PR as small as
possible since this change is non trivial and a bit dangerouse)
I can do that if you want, but I would prefer to do that in another pull
request since this modification is already a very sensible modification, I
don't want to risk breaking other things by doing too much at the same time.

I understand that you didn't wanted to modify to much things, but I've seen some remaining lines that could still cause some issues...

Which lines do you have in mind?

node.bodyText:
Hello,
A feature I've been talking about in the past: store in an individual "journals" files some operations like "installing an app" "remove an app" etc...
The idea is to ease debug (it's easy to find what has happen after) but also to empower web users who can't get access to those logs once they have close the tab or other similar behavior.
For now I'm only generating journals for app installation/remove/remove when installation failed/upgrade. We should probably introduce new journals like domain create (openssl stuff), apt related operations and other I can't thnink about right now.
This PR needs a bit of finishing work but it fully functional but I'm still opening it to get feedback,
See YunoHost/yunohost-admin#130 for the web admin integration.
It would be interesting to add helpers or other to ease the work of external libs to write journals to allow integration.
Here is the result of both commands:


End of previous command:

Weird format is due to mustache limitations.
Kinds regards,
I won't work on this branch soon, I'm waiting for other more important PR to be merged first.

node.bodyText:
The psutil.BOOT_TIME attribute appears to be deprecated, and returns an AttributeError when called.
Even though the psutil documentation states that old attributes should be callable, one should use psutil.boot_time() function instead.
In some version of psutil (e.g. 2.1.1), both appear callable. In old versions (e.g. 1.2.1), psutil.BOOT_TIME is but psutil.boot_time() is not. In the newest version (4.3.0), only the latter can be called.
This bug would introduce an Internal Server Error (Error 500) when accessing the Monitor tool in the YunoHost admin panel.

Thanks about that, actually, https://github.com/giampaolo/psutil/blob/release-2.1.1/psutil/__init__.py#L1964.

In the newest version (4.3.0), only the latter can be called.

Regarding Debian packages state, it's currently only the case if python-psutil is installed from jessie-backports or later.
Merged with 53e19fa.

node.title: Replace deprecated psutil.BOOT_TIME attribute
